block.p: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

''BERLIN TO BROADWAY WITH KURT WEILL,'' Triad, 158 West 72nd Street, (212) 239-6200. If this is not a flawless revue, it is nevertheless an ingratiating tribute to Kurt Weill's achievement. Fridays at 10:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 4:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Mondays and Tuesdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays at 3 p.m.; no performance Thursdays. Tickets: $45. Also at the Triad: ''Gershwin's American Rhapsody: A New Musical Revue,'' starring KT Sullivan and Mark Nadler. Fridays and Wednesdays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 5 and 10:15 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m.; Thursdays at 2 and 8 p.m. In previews; opens Nov. 10. Tickets: $40 to $55 (Lawrence Van Gelder).
A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

''BERLIN TO BROADWAY WITH KURT WEILL,'' Triad, 158 West 72nd Street, (212) 239-6200. If this is not a flawless revue, it is nevertheless an ingratiating tribute to Kurt Weill's achievement. Fridays at 10:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sundays at 4:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Mondays and Tuesdays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays at 3 p.m.; no performance Thursdays. Tickets: $45. Also at the Triad: ''Gershwin's American Rhapsody: A New Musical Revue,'' starring KT Sullivan and Mark Nadler. Fridays and Wednesdays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 5 and 10:15 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m.; Thursdays at 2 and 8 p.m. In previews; opens Nov. 10. Tickets: $40 to $55 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

BARBARA CARROLL, Bemelmans Bar, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. This agelessly chic red-haired pianist and singer seems to know every important popular song ever written and to be able to perform from memory in any key. Her elegant, lyrical pianism is a compendium of 20th-century jazz styles, from Count Basie to Erroll Garner to Bill Evans and beyond. And her clipped, understated vocals, which verge on speech-song, approach lyrics from a wry but warmhearted point of view. Tonight and tomorrow night beginning at 9:30, through Dec. 31. Michael Devine, Tuesdays through Saturdays at 5:30 p.m., through Dec. 30. Cover: $15 at table and $5 at the bar; no minimum (Stephen Holden).

* HOWARD FISHMAN QUARTET, Sardi's, 234 West 44th Street, (212) 221-8440. Powerful echoes of Stephane Grappelli and Bix Beiderbecke are among the influences rippling through the Howard Fishman Quartet's seamless swing. The group -- Mr. Fishman on guitar, banjo and vocals; Russell Farhang playing virtuosic Grappelli-style violin; Erik Jekabson on trumpet; and Jonathan Flaugher on bass -- folds elements of vintage jazz, swing and early bluegrass into rhythmically animated, richly allusive jazz chamber music. Whether the music is Stephen Foster (a bubbly ''Old Folks at Home''), Gershwin (''Soon'') or Romberg (''When I Grow Too Old to Dream''), it is all translated into lilting, fine-tuned ensemble music that transcends time and idiom. Fridays at 10:30 p.m. No cover charge, but $15 minimum at tables. The Howard Fishman Quartet also performs Sunday at 8:30 p.m. at Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. Tickets: $12 (Holden).

* ''OUR SINATRA,'' Reprise Room at Dillon's, 245 West 54th Street, (212) 239-6200. The rising young cabaret star Eric Comstock is the mastermind behind this utterly winning tribute to Ol' Blue Eyes. He focuses on what he calls the hidden gems and orphan songs that Sinatra made popular. Joined by Christopher Gines, whose creamy baritone echoes the voices of Dick Haymes and Steve Lawrence in their prime, and Hilary Kole, a perky swinger, Mr. Comstock conducts a witty and knowledgeable survey of the Sinatra canon. Mr. Comstock concentrates on the mature Sinatra, and Mr. Gines on the dreamy 1940's singer of ballads, with Ms. Kole bridging the gap. The memorable show proves that there are still young singers good enough to keep the tradition alive. Today and Monday through Wednesday at 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 2:30 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $50 and $55; ringside seating, $75 and $80 (Holden).

* BOBBY SHORT, Cafe Carlyle, at the Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. If his voice sometimes fogs up, and some nights are better than others, Mr. Short is still often capable of an exuberance that can make going to the Cafe Carlyle feel like attending the happiest and classiest private party in Manhattan. His new show includes a timely sequence of songs about money and a fresh selection of gems by Cole Porter, a longtime favorite of Mr. Short's. His excellent band gently kicks the material in a jazz direction. Through December. Tuesdays through Saturdays at 9 and 11 p.m. Cover: $60 at tables, no minimum; dinner available but not required, 6 p.m. to midnight. Monday nights at 8:45, through Dec. 17, Woody Allen with Eddy Davis's New Orleans Jazz Band. Cover: $60; no minimum (Holden).

* WESLA WHITFIELD, Arci's Place, 450 Park Avenue South, at 30th Street, (212) 532-4370. As she has grown more expressively uninhibited, Ms. Whitfield has metamorphosed from a complacent living-room entertainer into a complex, subtle interpreter who brings a double vision to her material. When performing, she often gives the sense that she is scouring the lyrics with an acute critical intelligence. At the same time, she conveys feelings that run from a sly, almost needling humor to profound pathos when letting loose on a ballad like ''How Deep Is the Ocean.'' Fridays and Saturdays at 8:30 and 11 p.m.; Tuesdays through Thursdays at 9 p.m. Through Nov. 14. Cover: $30; $15 minimum. Sunday night at 8 and 10, Saundra Santiago, singer. Cover: $25; $15 minimum. Mondays at 8, through Dec. 18, Jim Caruso, singer, in ''Live and in Person,'' with musical direction and piano accompaniment by Billy Stritch. Cover: $25; $15 minimum (Holden).

CAFE PIERRE, Fifth Avenue at 61st Street, (212) 940-8195. Kathleen Landis, singer and pianist, in ''Fascinating Rhythms: 50 Years of American Popular Song and Jazz, 1900-1950.'' Friday and Saturday nights from 8:30 to 12:30; Tuesday through Thursday nights from 8:30 to 11:30. Nancy Winston, Sunday and Monday nights from 8:30 to 11:30. No cover; $20 minimum.

CARNEGIE CLUB, 156 West 56th Street, (212) 957-9676. ''Weekends With Sinatra,'' with Cary Hoffman and the 11-piece Carnegie Club Orchestra, features music made famous by Frank Sinatra in the 1950's, with the original arrangements by Nelson Riddle. Friday and Saturday nights at 9:30 and 11. Cover, $20; two-drink ($15) minimum.

''CELEBRATE CY,'' Chelsea Piers, Pier 60, 23rd Street and Hudson River, (212) 302-5359. A 90th-birthday tribute to the director and producer Cy Feuer, including performances by Joel Grey, Robert Morse, Karen Ziemba, Walter Bobbie, Ellen Foley and Laura Benanti. Monday at 8:15 p.m.; cocktails at 6; dinner at 7. A benefit for the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers Foundation. Tickets: $50 to $500.

DANNY'S SKYLIGHT ROOM, 346 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 265-8133. Tonight from 9 to 1 in the piano bar, Jerry Scott. Tomorrow night from 5 to 9, Chuck Musone; from 9 to 1, Mr. Scott. Sunday night from 7 to 11, Sol Yaged and friends. Monday night at 7, ''Not Just Davyd,'' a variety show with Davyd Dean and Bill Zeffiro, pianist; at 9:15, David Berk, singer. Cover: none to $15, depending on the show; no minimum.

DON'T TELL MAMA, 343 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 757-0788. Tonight at 6, Alan Scott, singer; at 7, John Flynn, singer; at 8, ''The Next Big Broadway Musical,'' improvisational musical comedy; at 9, Marianne Challis, singer, with Christopher Marlowe, pianist. Tomorrow night at 6, Momsense, a musical-comedy troupe; at 8, Grace O'Connor, singer, with Christopher Marlowe, pianist; at 8:30 and 11, ''Poole Party!,'' with Ron Poole. Sunday at 5:30, ''The Divine Sarah Bernhardt,'' part 2, an original musical play by Robert Cabell; at 7, Helen Baldassare, singer, with Bobby Peaco, pianist; at 8, Mark McCombs, comedy characterization. Cover: free to $18, depending on the show. Two-drink minimum. No credit cards.

FIREBIRD CAFE, 363 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 586-0244. Steve Ross, singer, in ''Love and Laughter: The Sequel.'' Through Dec. 2. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11; Wednesdays and Thursdays at 9:30 p.m. Cover: $35; $15 minimum.

JUDY'S, 169 Eighth Avenue, at 18th Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-5410. Tonight at 8:30, Lee Dratfield, singer, in ''The World of Kurt Weill,'' with Woody Regan, pianist; at 11, Go Mahan, singer, in ''My Best, and Worst,'' with Peter Kiesewalter, pianist. Tomorrow night at 8:30, Judy Kreston and David Lahm, singers, in ''Fun, Laughs, Good Times,'' the lyrics of Dorothy Fields and Mr. Lahm, with Ratzo Harris, bassist; Eddie Caccavalle, drummer; at 11, Bianca Leigh, singer, with Lance Cruce, pianist, and Mary Rodriguez, drummer. Sunday at 3 p.m., Susan Baum, singer, in ''Taking a Chance,'' with Rolf Barnes, pianist; at 5:30, Elaine St. George, singer, in ''Do Re Mi, Democracy,'' with Julia Mendelsohn, pianist; at 8:30, Leslie Giammanco, singer, in ''Stage struck Me,'' with David Lahm, pianist and Ratzo Harris, bassist; at 11, Halloween benefit for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. Cover: $10 to $20; $10 minimum.

MICHAEL'S PUB, in the Renaissance New York Hotel, 714 Seventh Avenue, between 47th and 48th Streets, (212) 758-2272. ''Broadway Frolics,'' with Brady Schwind and Kate Jetmore, singers. Fridays and Saturdays at 9:30 and 11:30 p.m.; Tuesdays through Thursdays at 9:30 p.m. Cover: $25, Tuesday through Thursday; $30 for Friday and Saturday. Minimum: $15.

OAK ROOM, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 840-6800. Susannah McCorkle. Tuesdays through Thursdays at 9 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays at 9 and 11:30 p.m. Cover: $50, with dinner required for early shows on Fridays and Saturdays; $15 minimum for other shows; suggested dinner arrival for early show is 7. Through Nov. 25. Sunday brunch at 2 p.m. (seating begins at 12:30 p.m.), Sam Kaufman, singer, in ''I've Heard That Song Before.'' Cover: $50, including brunch; $25 for show only.

UPSTAIRS AT ROSE'S TURN, 55 Grove Street, West Village, (212) 366-5438. Tonight at 7, ''Around the World in a Bad Mood,'' comedy; at 9, ''The Elephant Man: The Musical,'' comedy; at 11, ''The Candy Comedy Hour.'' Tomorrow night at 7, ''Something Funny's Going On''; at 9, ''Hell in a Handbasket''; at 11, ''The Candy Comedy Hour.'' Sunday night at 7, ''Jim Allen's Piano Bar Hell-O,'' musical revue. Monday night at 7, Tony Furio, singer; 7, ''Hell in a Handbasket.'' Cover: $5 to $10; two-drink minimum. No credit cards.
